snippet: According to a new book, “Blood Sport: Alex Rodriguez, Biogenesis and the Quest to End Baseball’s Steroid Era,” Alex Rodriguez was granted a therapeutic-use exemption to take testosterone in 2007, the year he won his third M.V.P. award.
abstract: New book Blood Sport: Alex Rodriguez, Biogenesis and the Quest to End Baseball by Tim Elfrink and Gus Garcia-Roberts reveals that during Alex Rodriguez's MVP season in 2007, the New York Yankees slugger took performance-enhancing drug testosterone with the blessing of the doctor who oversaw Major League Baseball's drug-testing program; disclosure raises new questions about how baseball's therapeutic use exemptions are granted.
lead_paragraph: According to a new book, “Blood Sport: Alex Rodriguez, Biogenesis and the Quest to End Baseball’s Steroid Era,” Alex Rodriguez was granted a therapeutic-use exemption to take testosterone in 2007, the year he won his third M.V.P. award.

headline.main: Baseball Let Rodriguez Use Testosterone in Big Year, Book Says
headline.print_headline: Baseball Let Rodriguez Use Testosterone in Big Year, Book Says
